THE NEWS-LETTER.
Vol. VII.

APRIL 2, 1903.

No. 12.

COLLEGE MEN AND MANNERS.
. N article which appeared in the Aulion several months ago dealing with the
compatibility of culture with a university education has aroused no little
discussion. The article in question is entitled, "Observations in a Big
University," and deals with student life at a large Western university. Although
the immediate point at issue, an arraignment of the free higher educational institutions of the West, may not have so much bearing upon university education in
the East, nevertheless the vital question underlying the entire article concerns the
whole country, the East as well as the West. The question which is asked, and
one which seems to have elicited no satisfactory answer, is: Does the average
college student have good manners? Or perhaps it might be stated better: Has
education an absolutely refining value?
If we may accept as a postulate the statement that to-day education does not
exert an absolutely refining influence we do not have to seek far for what may
serve as reasons. A refining influence is exerted by association, and if the student lacking in refinement is not thrown into contact with his superiors he can
not hope to acquire by unconscious effort that ease and grace of manner which
should denote the college man.
It is generally accepted as true that a college education means more than mere
"book-learning." In the admirable democracy which as a rule characterizes college life a man learns a great deal from contact with his fellows. It is not the
dig who gets the most out of a course at college, although he may rank easily
first in his classes, but it is the man who rubs elbows with his fellows who gets the
better training. If he learns to give hard blows, he also learns to bear them unflinchingly in return. If he gives up the careful influence of home life by going
away to college, he gets in return a confidence and a self-reliance which will stand
him in good stead in the future. But are all these things conducive to good mantiers? Not at all. They give self-control, self-reliance, and confidence, but they
do not necessarily give that urbanity of manner which should designate the
college man.
One thing which marks the decay of manners among college men is the
lack of personal interest between the instructor and his class. It is not the fault
of one more than the other. In this present day and generation the instructor
is so busily engaged in his research work that he has little time to devote to his
classes. It is true that he grudgingly gives an hour to the men who are consigned to his care, but after the close of that hour he might as well be an inhabitant of another planet. ITe is engrossed in the studies which he hopes will make
his name famous, but in his selfish seclusion he forgets that there is a duty which
•

11

2

THE NEWS LETTER.

he owes to the students. He is engaged in making scholars of them, if such a
thing is possible, but at any cost he should try to make men of them, men in every
sense of the word. That should stand before everything else; that is what a
college education should do, if nothing else can ever be accomplished.
We hear much of the influence exerted upon the men of the first half of the
nineteenth century by their professors at college. This is particularly true of that
coterie of famous men who obtained their training in the smaller colleges of New
England. The professor was in personal touch with the men. He knew each
one ; he knew his struggles, his weaknesses, his temptations, and his ambitions. A
kind word or a helping hand at the right time was the making of many a man.
The perplexed youth knew that there was a sympathetic ear into which he could
pour his troubles. He knew that he had a kind friend who was always willing to
be a guide. and a counselor. Consequently those men received a training which
was of 'inestimable value.
There is another side. No one would believe for a moment that it is all the
fault of the instructor; far from it. The colleges to which reference has just been
made were all small institutions. It was easily possible for the president of the
university to know personally every man. To-day such a thing is out of the
question. The large colleges and universities have from one to four thousand
students. The professor reads his lectures to a large class of men, few of whom
he would know if he met them on the street. Jn such a case it would be absurd
to expect that close union which does so much for the undergraduate. It can not
be denied that even in the majority of cases where the professor makes advances
to the men in the class he is repulsed, because they seem to take a delight in
imposing upon a man who tries to introduce any binding tie of comradeship. The
result is not a satisfactory one to either side.
This lack of sympathy between the professor and his men may be one of the
causes of the decay of college manners. The college man is left to his own
devices, he is thrown upon his own resources. Does the professor care how the
man spends his time outside the classroom? Apparently not. Does he know
whether that man is engaged in playing football, or in playing the slot machine,
whether he is sitting at a table studying, or sitting at a table drawing to three
jacks and a queen? If he guesses it from his knowledge of the man gained in
the classroom he never makes any use of that interesting information. If the man
maintains a passing grade he lives his life as he pleases to the end of the chapter.
The author of "Observations in a Big University" asserts that the men who
work their way through college are only so much dead Wood, and that for them
education has no refining value. But such an argument can not be advanced to
strengthen the claim that college manners have deteriorated. These men are not
so much dead wood ; they can be found in every college taking an active interest
in all the pure sports and recreations in which college students delight. Colleges
need more of them. A man who is working his way is serious in his pursuit of
knowledge; he has a definite aim in life and he is getting an education because it
will further that aim. Such graduates are better advertisements for a college

. THE NEWS LETTER.
than the men who go to college for the social standing it will give them or because the only other alternative is to go to work.
There was once a time when it was truly an honor to be a college man. Now
it is very different. Men seem to go through college without giving a thought
to the fact that they are receiving a training which is far more comprehensive and
more thorough than that which falls to the lot of most young men. And because
it ,has lost that certain dignity in the eyes of the men themselves it can no longer
maintain that dignity in the eyes of others. If the college man refuses to accept
himself seriously, how can he expect others to do so?
We should imagine that the best, the purest English would be spoken by
college men. If the purity of the English language is to be preserved, who will
preserve it if not the men who are trained by education? But the fact is that there
are no more inveterate users of slang, as a class, than college men. Perhaps the
best criterion of a man is the language he uses ; if that is the case the public would
be warranted in declaring that college manners are not what they once were, and
that education no longer exerts a refining influence.
A college education does not in itself exert a refining influence. It should
teach a man to separate the true from the false, to recognize the true and to
appreciate it. Yet it can not compel him to do so. The writer of this article may
have gone far afield in attempting to find causes for this lack of manners, and he
is fully conscious that he has offered no suggestion which in any way can help in
arriving at a solution of the problem. All that he has done, and all that he has
attempted to do, is to throw some light upon some of the apparent causes.

SENIORS WIN DEBATE.
II V, sixth annual inter-class debate, now rapidly fading into remote college
_ history, was outwardly very much like its fine predecessors. There was
the same dignified march with mandolin accompaniment, the same neat
introduction by the President, the usual time-honored gags by Dr. Lee, and the
same impassional oratorical assault and repulse. The debate recalled the contest
of last year, particularly, because the class of 1903 was represented by precisely
the same team and that team won.
As usual the decision of the judges failed to please everybody, least of all
the losing class ; but to the disinterested spectator it seemed as fair as any such
decision can be. Clearly the seniors won on delivery. Their advantage in argument, if they had any at all, was certainly very slight.
Plaggemeyer was all that was expected of him, deliberate, easy, and finished,
too finished, perhaps, so that he suggested the danger of over-training. A slight
tinge of Licking's tempestuous enthusiasm would have done him no harm. Blum,
without his sarcasm and with more of a set speech, did better than last year, and
Strayer for some reason did not seem to do himself justice. Humrichouse is
on the way toward effective work, and another year when he is more at home on
the platform, will doubtless give a better account of himself. The dead-level

t

THE NEWS LETTER.

4

monotony of Rosenheim's speech was more than relieved by the variety and abar
don of Licking's. To those who have occasionally dropped in on the training Licking's performance seemed quite a tour de force. He overdid the part, to be sure,
and his style, taking as it was at first, soon began to pall on the audience which
it had stirred into generous good humor. His speech, however, was not merely
"hot air," to use a classic bit of debating slang; a good deal of it was really effective refutation,all the more to be commended because it had the air of being frankly
spontaneous.
This quality, by the way, was unfortunately lacking in most of the other
speeches. Debaters have learned by experience that a carefully-written memorized
speech, comfortably and calmly delivered, is more apt to win than a string of
halting, ill-phrased rejoinders. They ought to learn further that the speech of a
man who knows his subject and has learned by practice to think about it on his
feet and to put his thoughts into decent English on the spot, is much better than
either.
There is good reason, of course, why the .first speeches on both sides should
be memorized word for word and delivered with as much art as weeks of training
can inculcate; but there is no reason why the following speakers, or the first ones
either, for that matter, should have frequent recourse to the formula, "my opponents will doubtless say," and then proceed to demolish the arguments which they
have themselves set up. It is a good thing to know what one's opponents are going
to say, but it is wise to let them say it first. More than one good speech has gone
wide of the mark because the preceding speaker did not do what was expected of
him, and it was too late to change the polished phrases for something more
appropriate.
Aside from the fact that it furnished a last opportunity for the classes of 1903
and 1904 to try conclusions, the debate was interesting as a preliminary contest
to the inter-collegiate debate with North Carolina. Last year the visitors won by
a very narrow margin. We have now an opportunity to return the compliment.
If the men chosen to represent us will take the lessons of that debate and the recent
one to their hearts, and if the undergraduates, as a body, will encourage the team
with enthusiastic support, there is no reason why we may not beat North Carolina
on her own grounds.
The debate was preceded by the Freshmen speaking contest. The Lee prize
for excellence in public speaking was awarded to Goldman, who delivered l'earre's
address on Charles Carroll of Carrollton. Straugn and Zeigler were the other
speakers.
CONCERNING THE EASTER TRIP OF THE MUSICAL CLUBS
u RING the many meetings of the Fernandis Club there has been so much
discussion about the Easter trip of the Musical Clubs that an explanation
is perhaps permissible.
Since this is the first year in the history of the clubs that Old Point Comfort
has not been visited at Easter, it has caused much wonder and no little criticism

sp

•

THE NEWS LETTER.

!*

5

concerning the management.
Fi'om the beginning of the collegiate year, until a few weeks ago, there was
not the slightest doubt that the Hopkins men would once more enjoy their Spring
vacation at Fortress Monroe. There was every reason to believe that all plans
would be sucessful, for a contract signed by the manager of the Chamberlin and
Hygeia Hotels and the manager of the Musical Clubs was supposed to be sufficiently
binding.
Since the signing of the contracts, however, the Chamberlin Hotel has
changed managers, and the Hygeia is a thing of the past.
Last week a representative of the clubs was sent to Old Point to find if some
possible arrangements might be made by which the usual Easter trip could be
taken.
All argument was fruitless for the Hotel Chamberlin, even at that early date,
was well crowded, and every room in the house was already engaged for the
one time when Fortress Monroe awakens to life. Whether the hotel management
was aware of the contract made earlier in the year is a matter of speculation. The
legal status of the contract seemed to need no further investigation.
Of course, technically, the responsibility of the hotel is not shifted by the
change in managers; but as the contract was signed by the managers of the clubs,
a minor, the contract could not be valid. Then again, the Musical Clubs are not
a legal organization, and so a contract signed in their behalf would be purely a
personal matter.
This will perhaps clear the legal atmosphere, and show that the trip was not
lost through the negligence on the part of the manager.
It was hinted that the conduct of the men in past years might account for the
clubs not being able to return to Old Point. This was most assuredly not the
case, for there was less disorder last year than ever before. Indeed, the manager
of the hotels complimented the men on their excellent order.
In discussing the situation this year, the new manager seemed to be governed
alniost entirely by the scarcity of accommodations. It may be consoling to those
most interested to know that the Yale Base Ball Team has been unsuccessful in
its efforts to play its annual game at Old Point with the Artillery School. The
Cornell Musical Club were also so desirous of being at Old Point during the Easter
holidays that they sent their manager down to Old Point to engage accommodations. In this they were unsuccessful.
Where the clubs will go is still more interesting than why they will not go to
their usual "loafing grounds ;" but on this subject there is really a sad dearth of
information.
— Several places are being considered, and everything possible is being done to
find some place that will offer similar attractions to those offered by Old Point
Comfort.
If it were earlier in the year, a trip to Atlantic City might be a possibility ;
but at this late date an attempt to make such an expensive trip is out of the question. The most plausible plans include the "old Christmas trip" to Winchester,
Va.,Charlestown, W. Va.., Cambridge, and Easton of lower Maryland.

I I V, Nms-LErrER can not help being unrestrainedly jubilant over the Seventh
Annual Indoor Gaines given by the University last Saturday night, and to.
those indefatigable workers who have worked night and day to make the
meet a success the Nms-I,Erri.:R extends its heartiest congratulations. All previous games pale into insignificence when compared with them, and they will be
the standard by which future games must be judged. We have yet to find the
man who has a complaint to make. Mr, Hoffman, Mr. Dulany, Mr. Mackdermott, and the Games Committee have reached the highwater mark of athletic
success. Hopkins has always stood for what is purest and best in athletics, and
the splendid support given the games by the citizens of Baltimore bore witness
to the fact that the efforts of the University in striving to maintain a high standard
have received universal recognition.
In the first place the officials were selected solely on account of their fitness;
there was not one who was not thoroughly competent, and no competitor was
given an undue advantage on account of ignorance on the part of an official. The
University was fortunate in having secured the services of Mr. M. J. Thompson
of Georgetown as referee, and the selection of such a man was a guarantee that

Z

THE NEWS LETTER.

7

nothing but the wisest decisions would be rendered. As clerk of the course Mr.
Mackdtrmott was well fitted for the position through his long experience with
athletics. We were glad to see that it was not necessary to run trial heats in the
afternoon. Perhaps the best compliment of the evening came from the newspaper men. 'Mr. Mackdermott is a wonder," said one, "he is running off events
with such a snap that we can't keep up with him."
Athletically, our track team made an excellent showing, and the University
has good reason to be proud of its representatives. Every man ran for all that
was in him, and win or lose he helped maintain the glory of Hopkins. The success of this meet makes our visit to Virginia an assured fact, and in the dual meet
we hope to give the Virginians the hardest tussle they have ever had.

s its leading article for this issue THE Nims-LErrER publishes a short criticism of "College Men and Manners." The article is purely an academic
one, and has no reference to the Johns Hopkins University. In fact this
University may be regarded as in a class by itself, and it very often happens that
conditions which exist at other institutions can have no analogue here. Consequently many of the observations made on the relations of the students and the
faculty are entirely inapplicable to Hopkins. Some of the undergraduates have
complained, however, that the faculty do not support the student body in the matter
of athletics. Their contention is in part a fair one. They are wrong in imagining that they should have the support of the entire faculty, because there are a
great number who are thrown in contact with the undergraduates, and it would
be asking too much to expect them to witness an athletic game in which they had
no interest. But we have a right to expect those members of the faculty who are
engaged in teaching undergraduates to turn out to our games. On next Saturday the lacrosse team plays the first game of the season. On that occasion the
whole University, if possible, should be present to do honor to the 1 earn which more
than any other upholds the athletic renown of-the University.

material of a similar character is requested. Any man who is able to draw
would be helping the board greatly if he would turn his talent to account in assisting to make the book a success. There is only a week left in which matter can be
turned in, and those who are thinking of contributing will confer a favor on the
editors if they hand in their contributions at once.

The Hopkins Club has decided to vacate its present clubhouse in June, and is
looking for a house nearer the University.
On the night of March 19, Dr. George B. Shattuck delivered an illustrated
lecture on "The Florida Everglades," before the Geological Club of the Woman's
College.
Dr. J. B. Whitehead will be married on the 14th of April to Miss Mary
Colston of Baltimore.
Dr. C. W. Emil Miller, associate professor of Greek, has been chosen as first
reader of the Christian Science Church of Baltimore.
President Remsen delivered an address on "Education" before the members
of the Arundel] Club, on last Thursday.
Dr. W. J. Humphries, (Ph. D., 1897), who is now in the physics department
of the University of Virginia, and is engaged in special physical research,
came to Baltimore last week, in order to use some apparatus in the laboratory.
Dr. W. W. Willoughby has recently received a Japanese translation of his
work, "An Examination of the Nature of the State." This translation is one of
a number of translations of foreign works, which are being prepared under the
direction of, and published by the University of Tokyo. The Macmillin Company, the American publishers of this same work, have had Dr. Willoughby revise
it in preparation for a new edition which they will publish shortly. "The Rights
and Duties of American Citizenship," another of Dr. Willoughby's works, has
also been recently revised in preparation for a new edition. This work is published by the American Book Company.

Y. M. C. A. NOTES.
The. annual business meeting for the election of officers for the ensuing year
will be held on Tuesday, April 7th, at the close of a short devotional meeting
at 5 o'clock, led by Mr. J. M. Wright, Econ. It is desired that the members
attend. The nominating committee makes the following suggestions for the officers
President., Dr. H. L. Wilson; 1st Vice Pres., R. P. Stephens; and Vice Pres.,
R. 0. Fuerbringer ; Treasurer, F. G. Porter, Jr.; Rec. Secy., W. R. Straughn.
Executive Council, Dr. E. H. Griffin, D. W. Richardson, M. W. Twitchell,
J. F. Messick.
Owing to unavoidable conflict with Prof. Mabilleau's lecture in Levering Hall
the Association was requested to hold its Tuesday meeting March 31st in McCoy
Hall. Mr. J. M. Rice, Secretary of the Baltimore and Ohio Branch, spoke to
us about railroad association work.

THE NEWS LETTER.

The First Mission Study Class meets on alternate Sunday afternoons in Levering Hall, March 29th, April 12th, etc. Very interesting reports are now being
given on different lines of the work in India, and on the lives of some of the
great men who have worked there. Any men who desire to take part in such a
course are invited to join us now for the rest of the year.
The second class meets on Tuesday at 1.2 o'clock for one-half hour. This
is a splendid opportunity for men who have never taken such a course before.

NEW BOOKS BY HOPKINS MEN.
Dr. Wm. A. Scott, Ph. D., '92, who is Professor of Economic History and
Theory, at the University of Wisconsin, is the author of "Money and Banking,
An Introduction to the Study of Modern Currency." In the introduction Professor Scott states that the subject of his work is "modern currency, and it aims
to analyze and explain the complex media of exchange of the great nations of the
present day in such a way as to reveal the nature and working of each element,
and the relations between them all. Besides money in the ordinary sense therefore, it includes a discussion of banks in their relation to the currency, of the various forms of government notes, and of all the machinery and methods of international exchange."
"Hebraisms in the Authorized Version of the Bible," by Dr. Wm. Rosenau,
is a recent publication of the Freidenwald Co., of this city. The work is a valuable
contribution to the study of modern English, and will lead to a better understanding of the Authorized Version. Dr. Rosenau's main object, in which he succeeds most admirably, is to point out the influence of the Biblical Hebrew upon the
English of the Authorized Version syntactically and lexiocographically.
The Macmillan Co. have recently published "The Principles of Dyeing," by
Geo. S. Fraps, Ph. D., '99, who is now Professor of Chemistry, North Carolina
College of Agriculture and Mechanic Arts. Dr. Frap's work is a systematic
presentation of the principles underlying the art of dyeing, illustrated and emphasized by laboratory exercises.

THE HOPKINS ARMORY GAMES.

•

fro ITHOUT a single unpleasant feature to detract froin the success of the
occasion, the Johns Hopkins indoor track and field games were held last
Saturday evening before an immense gathering in the Fifth Regiment
Armory, where more than 250 contestants competed, representing 26 colleges,
schools, and athletic organizations. The meet was the most successful ever held
in this section, and fully realized the highest expectations of those who had been
most sanguine of success. From beginning to end, one event followed another
in rapid succession, thus eliminating those long, tedious delays that usually occur
to diminish the enjoyment of such events ; furthermore, the usual crowded infield
was lacking, none but officials and a few contestants being allowed inside the track,
so that the audience had a clear view of the entire field of action. Prof. Wm. M.
Mackdermott. the Clerk of Course, and the other officials, have been highly commended for the able manner in which the games were conducted, and well may
they. feel that their untiring efforts were productive of most satisfactory results.
In addition to the customary events, Arthur F. Duffy of Georgetown University, who holds the world's record of 9 3-5 seconds for 100 yards, gave an exhibition 35-yard dash, equaling the present world's record of 4.,seconds fiat. The
Relay Races, of which there were ten, were unusually interesting and exciting,
especially those between M. A. C. and B. A. C., between the Emerson Institute
of Washington and 'Marston's. Hopkins unfortunately was unable to secure a
worthy team to compete with her.
Hopkins easily made the best showing of any organization represented. In
each of the events in which her men were entered, at least one of them always
secured a place. Individual honors were carried off by Harry K. Tootle who distinguished himself by captivating three firsts—in the 35-yard scratch and 35-yard
open handicap dashes, and in the .140-yard handicap. In the 35-yard handicap
Pessagno broke the State record, his time being 4. 1-5 seconds. J. A. Freeze was a
close second to Tootle for first honors, finishing first in both the Shot Put and 40yard hurdle, and second in the 440-yard handicap.
Following is a brief summary of the events that are of special interest to
Hopkins men:

THE NEWS LETTER.

OPENING OF THE LACROSSE SEASON.
INCE our track and field team wound up its indoor season in a glorious
finish at the Fifth Regiment Armory last Saturday night, the attention of
the undergraduates has naturally turned to lacrosse ; and well that it should,
for this Saturday afternoon the opening game will be played at the American
League Park against the University of Pennsylvania.
Last year Pennsylvania was defeated on Franklin Field by a score of 5 to 1
goals, but when it is remembered that Lehigh was beaten 9 to 1, Harvard, 11 to
1, and Columbia 17 to 1, we readily see that Pennsy is no mean antagonist. When
we also consider the fact that Hopkins will hardly turn out as strong a team as
that of last season, and that Pennsy is growing stronger each year, it may easily
be seen that the game Saturday is apt to be well contested.
For several weeks past the Hopkins squad has been doing steady, faithful
work on the Druid Hill Park campus, and the results have for the most part been
very encouraging. Team work has gradually developed and the men have daily
shown better form and condition.
From the present outlook, it may safely be said that at no time in the history
of Hopkins lacrosse have the new candidates had a better chance to figure in one
or more contests during the season. This is especially true of the attack. Should
B. Bernheim be unable to fill his old position at out home, foul' places out of the
six will be open. Putts is the remaining home man, and Bird is the only midfield
man left from last year's attack. Matthai and Strohbar seem reasonably sure of
positions, and should they play at centre and first attack respectively, with Putts
at inhome and Bird at third attack, second attack and outhome will still be vacant.
For these positions Foster, Taylor, Hoffman, Dill and Pearre are dividing honors.
Foster, it will be remembered, played on the 1900 championship team, and should
he find time for practice, will prove a very available man.
The defense did not suffer such severe losses at the close of the past season,
Captain Schmeisser being the only man to graduate. From present prospects
E. Schmeisser and Blanck will mow back one position, thus leaving second defense vacant. Custis will probably make the place.
The schedule as 'arranged by Manager J. A. Addison is undoubtedly one of
the hardest we have ever faced. Not only is Stevens Institute an extra antagonist
for the possession of the championship pennant, but the Crescent Athletic Club
and the Toronto Twelve are to be played. The Varsity team will do its part,
but encouragement is needed as well as reasonably expected; and it is up to you.
The team will do some light stick work in the cage Friday afternoon, and Chiefrooter Plaggemeyer wants every man to turn out in the gallery at 5 o'clock for yell
practice. Don't forget it: Friday, 5 o'clock.

Vol. VII.

APRIL 2, 1903.

No. 12.

COLLEGE MEN AND MANNERS.
. N article which appeared in the Aulion several months ago dealing with the
compatibility of culture with a university education has aroused no little
discussion. The article in question is entitled, "Observations in a Big
University," and deals with student life at a large Western university. Although
the immediate point at issue, an arraignment of the free higher educational institutions of the West, may not have so much bearing upon university education in
the East, nevertheless the vital question underlying the entire article concerns the
whole country, the East as well as the West. The question which is asked, and
one which seems to have elicited no satisfactory answer, is: Does the average
college student have good manners? Or perhaps it might be stated better: Has
education an absolutely refining value?
If we may accept as a postulate the statement that to-day education does not
exert an absolutely refining influence we do not have to seek far for what may
serve as reasons. A refining influence is exerted by association, and if the student lacking in refinement is not thrown into contact with his superiors he can
not hope to acquire by unconscious effort that ease and grace of manner which
should denote the college man.
It is generally accepted as true that a college education means more than mere
"book-learning." In the admirable democracy which as a rule characterizes college life a man learns a great deal from contact with his fellows. It is not the
dig who gets the most out of a course at college, although he may rank easily
first in his classes, but it is the man who rubs elbows with his fellows who gets the
better training. If he learns to give hard blows, he also learns to bear them unflinchingly in return. If he gives up the careful influence of home life by going
away to college, he gets in return a confidence and a self-reliance which will stand
him in good stead in the future. But are all these things conducive to good mantiers? Not at all. They give self-control, self-reliance, and confidence, but they
do not necessarily give that urbanity of manner which should designate the
college man.
One thing which marks the decay of manners among college men is the
lack of personal interest between the instructor and his class. It is not the fault
of one more than the other. In this present day and generation the instructor
is so busily engaged in his research work that he has little time to devote to his
classes. It is true that he grudgingly gives an hour to the men who are consigned to his care, but after the close of that hour he might as well be an inhabitant of another planet. ITe is engrossed in the studies which he hopes will make
his name famous, but in his selfish seclusion he forgets that there is a duty which
•

11

2

THE NEWS LETTER.

he owes to the students. He is engaged in making scholars of them, if such a
thing is possible, but at any cost he should try to make men of them, men in every
sense of the word. That should stand before everything else; that is what a
college education should do, if nothing else can ever be accomplished.
We hear much of the influence exerted upon the men of the first half of the
nineteenth century by their professors at college. This is particularly true of that
coterie of famous men who obtained their training in the smaller colleges of New
England. The professor was in personal touch with the men. He knew each
one ; he knew his struggles, his weaknesses, his temptations, and his ambitions. A
kind word or a helping hand at the right time was the making of many a man.
The perplexed youth knew that there was a sympathetic ear into which he could
pour his troubles. He knew that he had a kind friend who was always willing to
be a guide. and a counselor. Consequently those men received a training which
was of 'inestimable value.
There is another side. No one would believe for a moment that it is all the
fault of the instructor; far from it. The colleges to which reference has just been
made were all small institutions. It was easily possible for the president of the
university to know personally every man. To-day such a thing is out of the
question. The large colleges and universities have from one to four thousand
students. The professor reads his lectures to a large class of men, few of whom
he would know if he met them on the street. Jn such a case it would be absurd
to expect that close union which does so much for the undergraduate. It can not
be denied that even in the majority of cases where the professor makes advances
to the men in the class he is repulsed, because they seem to take a delight in
imposing upon a man who tries to introduce any binding tie of comradeship. The
result is not a satisfactory one to either side.
This lack of sympathy between the professor and his men may be one of the
causes of the decay of college manners. The college man is left to his own
devices, he is thrown upon his own resources. Does the professor care how the
man spends his time outside the classroom? Apparently not. Does he know
whether that man is engaged in playing football, or in playing the slot machine,
whether he is sitting at a table studying, or sitting at a table drawing to three
jacks and a queen? If he guesses it from his knowledge of the man gained in
the classroom he never makes any use of that interesting information. If the man
maintains a passing grade he lives his life as he pleases to the end of the chapter.
The author of "Observations in a Big University" asserts that the men who
work their way through college are only so much dead Wood, and that for them
education has no refining value. But such an argument can not be advanced to
strengthen the claim that college manners have deteriorated. These men are not
so much dead wood ; they can be found in every college taking an active interest
in all the pure sports and recreations in which college students delight. Colleges
need more of them. A man who is working his way is serious in his pursuit of
knowledge; he has a definite aim in life and he is getting an education because it
will further that aim. Such graduates are better advertisements for a college

. THE NEWS LETTER.
than the men who go to college for the social standing it will give them or because the only other alternative is to go to work.
There was once a time when it was truly an honor to be a college man. Now
it is very different. Men seem to go through college without giving a thought
to the fact that they are receiving a training which is far more comprehensive and
more thorough than that which falls to the lot of most young men. And because
it ,has lost that certain dignity in the eyes of the men themselves it can no longer
maintain that dignity in the eyes of others. If the college man refuses to accept
himself seriously, how can he expect others to do so?
We should imagine that the best, the purest English would be spoken by
college men. If the purity of the English language is to be preserved, who will
preserve it if not the men who are trained by education? But the fact is that there
are no more inveterate users of slang, as a class, than college men. Perhaps the
best criterion of a man is the language he uses ; if that is the case the public would
be warranted in declaring that college manners are not what they once were, and
that education no longer exerts a refining influence.
A college education does not in itself exert a refining influence. It should
teach a man to separate the true from the false, to recognize the true and to
appreciate it. Yet it can not compel him to do so. The writer of this article may
have gone far afield in attempting to find causes for this lack of manners, and he
is fully conscious that he has offered no suggestion which in any way can help in
arriving at a solution of the problem. All that he has done, and all that he has
attempted to do, is to throw some light upon some of the apparent causes.

SENIORS WIN DEBATE.
II V, sixth annual inter-class debate, now rapidly fading into remote college
_ history, was outwardly very much like its fine predecessors. There was
the same dignified march with mandolin accompaniment, the same neat
introduction by the President, the usual time-honored gags by Dr. Lee, and the
same impassional oratorical assault and repulse. The debate recalled the contest
of last year, particularly, because the class of 1903 was represented by precisely
the same team and that team won.
As usual the decision of the judges failed to please everybody, least of all
the losing class ; but to the disinterested spectator it seemed as fair as any such
decision can be. Clearly the seniors won on delivery. Their advantage in argument, if they had any at all, was certainly very slight.
Plaggemeyer was all that was expected of him, deliberate, easy, and finished,
too finished, perhaps, so that he suggested the danger of over-training. A slight
tinge of Licking's tempestuous enthusiasm would have done him no harm. Blum,
without his sarcasm and with more of a set speech, did better than last year, and
Strayer for some reason did not seem to do himself justice. Humrichouse is
on the way toward effective work, and another year when he is more at home on
the platform, will doubtless give a better account of himself. The dead-level

t

THE NEWS LETTER.

4

monotony of Rosenheim's speech was more than relieved by the variety and abar
don of Licking's. To those who have occasionally dropped in on the training Licking's performance seemed quite a tour de force. He overdid the part, to be sure,
and his style, taking as it was at first, soon began to pall on the audience which
it had stirred into generous good humor. His speech, however, was not merely
"hot air," to use a classic bit of debating slang; a good deal of it was really effective refutation,all the more to be commended because it had the air of being frankly
spontaneous.
This quality, by the way, was unfortunately lacking in most of the other
speeches. Debaters have learned by experience that a carefully-written memorized
speech, comfortably and calmly delivered, is more apt to win than a string of
halting, ill-phrased rejoinders. They ought to learn further that the speech of a
man who knows his subject and has learned by practice to think about it on his
feet and to put his thoughts into decent English on the spot, is much better than
either.
There is good reason, of course, why the .first speeches on both sides should
be memorized word for word and delivered with as much art as weeks of training
can inculcate; but there is no reason why the following speakers, or the first ones
either, for that matter, should have frequent recourse to the formula, "my opponents will doubtless say," and then proceed to demolish the arguments which they
have themselves set up. It is a good thing to know what one's opponents are going
to say, but it is wise to let them say it first. More than one good speech has gone
wide of the mark because the preceding speaker did not do what was expected of
him, and it was too late to change the polished phrases for something more
appropriate.
Aside from the fact that it furnished a last opportunity for the classes of 1903
and 1904 to try conclusions, the debate was interesting as a preliminary contest
to the inter-collegiate debate with North Carolina. Last year the visitors won by
a very narrow margin. We have now an opportunity to return the compliment.
If the men chosen to represent us will take the lessons of that debate and the recent
one to their hearts, and if the undergraduates, as a body, will encourage the team
with enthusiastic support, there is no reason why we may not beat North Carolina
on her own grounds.
The debate was preceded by the Freshmen speaking contest. The Lee prize
for excellence in public speaking was awarded to Goldman, who delivered l'earre's
address on Charles Carroll of Carrollton. Straugn and Zeigler were the other
speakers.
CONCERNING THE EASTER TRIP OF THE MUSICAL CLUBS
u RING the many meetings of the Fernandis Club there has been so much
discussion about the Easter trip of the Musical Clubs that an explanation
is perhaps permissible.
Since this is the first year in the history of the clubs that Old Point Comfort
has not been visited at Easter, it has caused much wonder and no little criticism

sp

•

THE NEWS LETTER.

!*

5

concerning the management.
Fi'om the beginning of the collegiate year, until a few weeks ago, there was
not the slightest doubt that the Hopkins men would once more enjoy their Spring
vacation at Fortress Monroe. There was every reason to believe that all plans
would be sucessful, for a contract signed by the manager of the Chamberlin and
Hygeia Hotels and the manager of the Musical Clubs was supposed to be sufficiently
binding.
Since the signing of the contracts, however, the Chamberlin Hotel has
changed managers, and the Hygeia is a thing of the past.
Last week a representative of the clubs was sent to Old Point to find if some
possible arrangements might be made by which the usual Easter trip could be
taken.
All argument was fruitless for the Hotel Chamberlin, even at that early date,
was well crowded, and every room in the house was already engaged for the
one time when Fortress Monroe awakens to life. Whether the hotel management
was aware of the contract made earlier in the year is a matter of speculation. The
legal status of the contract seemed to need no further investigation.
Of course, technically, the responsibility of the hotel is not shifted by the
change in managers; but as the contract was signed by the managers of the clubs,
a minor, the contract could not be valid. Then again, the Musical Clubs are not
a legal organization, and so a contract signed in their behalf would be purely a
personal matter.
This will perhaps clear the legal atmosphere, and show that the trip was not
lost through the negligence on the part of the manager.
It was hinted that the conduct of the men in past years might account for the
clubs not being able to return to Old Point. This was most assuredly not the
case, for there was less disorder last year than ever before. Indeed, the manager
of the hotels complimented the men on their excellent order.
In discussing the situation this year, the new manager seemed to be governed
alniost entirely by the scarcity of accommodations. It may be consoling to those
most interested to know that the Yale Base Ball Team has been unsuccessful in
its efforts to play its annual game at Old Point with the Artillery School. The
Cornell Musical Club were also so desirous of being at Old Point during the Easter
holidays that they sent their manager down to Old Point to engage accommodations. In this they were unsuccessful.
Where the clubs will go is still more interesting than why they will not go to
their usual "loafing grounds ;" but on this subject there is really a sad dearth of
information.
— Several places are being considered, and everything possible is being done to
find some place that will offer similar attractions to those offered by Old Point
Comfort.
If it were earlier in the year, a trip to Atlantic City might be a possibility ;
but at this late date an attempt to make such an expensive trip is out of the question. The most plausible plans include the "old Christmas trip" to Winchester,
Va.,Charlestown, W. Va.., Cambridge, and Easton of lower Maryland.

I I V, Nms-LErrER can not help being unrestrainedly jubilant over the Seventh
Annual Indoor Gaines given by the University last Saturday night, and to.
those indefatigable workers who have worked night and day to make the
meet a success the Nms-I,Erri.:R extends its heartiest congratulations. All previous games pale into insignificence when compared with them, and they will be
the standard by which future games must be judged. We have yet to find the
man who has a complaint to make. Mr, Hoffman, Mr. Dulany, Mr. Mackdermott, and the Games Committee have reached the highwater mark of athletic
success. Hopkins has always stood for what is purest and best in athletics, and
the splendid support given the games by the citizens of Baltimore bore witness
to the fact that the efforts of the University in striving to maintain a high standard
have received universal recognition.
In the first place the officials were selected solely on account of their fitness;
there was not one who was not thoroughly competent, and no competitor was
given an undue advantage on account of ignorance on the part of an official. The
University was fortunate in having secured the services of Mr. M. J. Thompson
of Georgetown as referee, and the selection of such a man was a guarantee that

s its leading article for this issue THE Nims-LErrER publishes a short criticism of "College Men and Manners." The article is purely an academic
one, and has no reference to the Johns Hopkins University. In fact this
University may be regarded as in a class by itself, and it very often happens that
conditions which exist at other institutions can have no analogue here. Consequently many of the observations made on the relations of the students and the
faculty are entirely inapplicable to Hopkins. Some of the undergraduates have
complained, however, that the faculty do not support the student body in the matter
of athletics. Their contention is in part a fair one. They are wrong in imagining that they should have the support of the entire faculty, because there are a
great number who are thrown in contact with the undergraduates, and it would
be asking too much to expect them to witness an athletic game in which they had
no interest. But we have a right to expect those members of the faculty who are
engaged in teaching undergraduates to turn out to our games. On next Saturday the lacrosse team plays the first game of the season. On that occasion the
whole University, if possible, should be present to do honor to the 1 earn which more
than any other upholds the athletic renown of-the University.

NEW BOOKS BY HOPKINS MEN.
Dr. Wm. A. Scott, Ph. D., '92, who is Professor of Economic History and
Theory, at the University of Wisconsin, is the author of "Money and Banking,
An Introduction to the Study of Modern Currency." In the introduction Professor Scott states that the subject of his work is "modern currency, and it aims
to analyze and explain the complex media of exchange of the great nations of the
present day in such a way as to reveal the nature and working of each element,
and the relations between them all. Besides money in the ordinary sense therefore, it includes a discussion of banks in their relation to the currency, of the various forms of government notes, and of all the machinery and methods of international exchange."
"Hebraisms in the Authorized Version of the Bible," by Dr. Wm. Rosenau,
is a recent publication of the Freidenwald Co., of this city. The work is a valuable
contribution to the study of modern English, and will lead to a better understanding of the Authorized Version. Dr. Rosenau's main object, in which he succeeds most admirably, is to point out the influence of the Biblical Hebrew upon the
English of the Authorized Version syntactically and lexiocographically.
The Macmillan Co. have recently published "The Principles of Dyeing," by
Geo. S. Fraps, Ph. D., '99, who is now Professor of Chemistry, North Carolina
College of Agriculture and Mechanic Arts. Dr. Frap's work is a systematic
presentation of the principles underlying the art of dyeing, illustrated and emphasized by laboratory exercises.

THE HOPKINS ARMORY GAMES.

•

fro ITHOUT a single unpleasant feature to detract froin the success of the
occasion, the Johns Hopkins indoor track and field games were held last
Saturday evening before an immense gathering in the Fifth Regiment
Armory, where more than 250 contestants competed, representing 26 colleges,
schools, and athletic organizations. The meet was the most successful ever held
in this section, and fully realized the highest expectations of those who had been
most sanguine of success. From beginning to end, one event followed another
in rapid succession, thus eliminating those long, tedious delays that usually occur
to diminish the enjoyment of such events ; furthermore, the usual crowded infield
was lacking, none but officials and a few contestants being allowed inside the track,
so that the audience had a clear view of the entire field of action. Prof. Wm. M.
Mackdermott. the Clerk of Course, and the other officials, have been highly commended for the able manner in which the games were conducted, and well may
they. feel that their untiring efforts were productive of most satisfactory results.
In addition to the customary events, Arthur F. Duffy of Georgetown University, who holds the world's record of 9 3-5 seconds for 100 yards, gave an exhibition 35-yard dash, equaling the present world's record of 4.,seconds fiat. The
Relay Races, of which there were ten, were unusually interesting and exciting,
especially those between M. A. C. and B. A. C., between the Emerson Institute
of Washington and 'Marston's. Hopkins unfortunately was unable to secure a
worthy team to compete with her.
Hopkins easily made the best showing of any organization represented. In
each of the events in which her men were entered, at least one of them always
secured a place. Individual honors were carried off by Harry K. Tootle who distinguished himself by captivating three firsts—in the 35-yard scratch and 35-yard
open handicap dashes, and in the .140-yard handicap. In the 35-yard handicap
Pessagno broke the State record, his time being 4. 1-5 seconds. J. A. Freeze was a
close second to Tootle for first honors, finishing first in both the Shot Put and 40yard hurdle, and second in the 440-yard handicap.

world's record M r. Pessagno is to be congratulated on establishing such a record
for Maryland.

THE NEWS LETTER.

OPENING OF THE LACROSSE SEASON.
INCE our track and field team wound up its indoor season in a glorious
finish at the Fifth Regiment Armory last Saturday night, the attention of
the undergraduates has naturally turned to lacrosse ; and well that it should,
for this Saturday afternoon the opening game will be played at the American
League Park against the University of Pennsylvania.
Last year Pennsylvania was defeated on Franklin Field by a score of 5 to 1
goals, but when it is remembered that Lehigh was beaten 9 to 1, Harvard, 11 to
1, and Columbia 17 to 1, we readily see that Pennsy is no mean antagonist. When
we also consider the fact that Hopkins will hardly turn out as strong a team as
that of last season, and that Pennsy is growing stronger each year, it may easily
be seen that the game Saturday is apt to be well contested.
For several weeks past the Hopkins squad has been doing steady, faithful
work on the Druid Hill Park campus, and the results have for the most part been
very encouraging. Team work has gradually developed and the men have daily
shown better form and condition.
From the present outlook, it may safely be said that at no time in the history
of Hopkins lacrosse have the new candidates had a better chance to figure in one
or more contests during the season. This is especially true of the attack. Should
B. Bernheim be unable to fill his old position at out home, foul' places out of the
six will be open. Putts is the remaining home man, and Bird is the only midfield
man left from last year's attack. Matthai and Strohbar seem reasonably sure of
positions, and should they play at centre and first attack respectively, with Putts
at inhome and Bird at third attack, second attack and outhome will still be vacant.
For these positions Foster, Taylor, Hoffman, Dill and Pearre are dividing honors.
Foster, it will be remembered, played on the 1900 championship team, and should
he find time for practice, will prove a very available man.
The defense did not suffer such severe losses at the close of the past season,
Captain Schmeisser being the only man to graduate. From present prospects
E. Schmeisser and Blanck will mow back one position, thus leaving second defense vacant. Custis will probably make the place.
The schedule as 'arranged by Manager J. A. Addison is undoubtedly one of
the hardest we have ever faced. Not only is Stevens Institute an extra antagonist
for the possession of the championship pennant, but the Crescent Athletic Club
and the Toronto Twelve are to be played. The Varsity team will do its part,
but encouragement is needed as well as reasonably expected; and it is up to you.
The team will do some light stick work in the cage Friday afternoon, and Chiefrooter Plaggemeyer wants every man to turn out in the gallery at 5 o'clock for yell
practice. Don't forget it: Friday, 5 o'clock.
